name: soybean production | soybean | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/28716/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of soybean (fresh matter) in the US state of North Dakota at farm, with a pre-drying moisture content of 13.1%. This dataset includes cultivation of the field prior to planting, field treatments, planting, applications of nutrients and pesticides, and harvest.;The average yield of soybean grown in North Dakota for the 2014-2021 seasons was 2,165 kg/ha (wet mass) (USDA NASS (2021)).  The dataset reflects the average soybean produced in North Dakota from 2014 to 2021, inclusive, as that period allows for at least one value from USDA statistics for most parameters and generally three or more.  It reflects the mix of tillage practices (42% no till, 44% reduced till, 13% conventional tillage) (CTIC (2020a) )  and rotations (100% in rotation with maize) for soy bean.  About 95% of planted soybean is genetically engineered for herbicide tolerance (USDA NASS 2021). This dataset reflects practices consistent with that.;Area, productivity, use of mineral and organic fertilisers and pesticides, and irrigation inputs are based on farmer data reported to the U.S. Department of Agriculture. Because soybean is primarily grown in annual rotation with maize, lime use is based on soil pH and guidance from agricultural extension offices for maize cultivation and its application is associated with the maize production system; this dataset does not include lime application attributed to soybean. Field operations and equipment types and fuel use are based on materials provided to growers by the agricultural extension office(s), including farm budgets, and on survey information agricultural extension office(s) collect from growers, in conjunction with row spacing data from USDA.  Drainage (tile or ditch) is installed on 8.3% based on state-level agricultural survey data from USDA.  Irrigation is included based on share of crop irrigated (less than 0.6% over the time period, USDA NASS (2018)). Chemigation is included in this and is not treated as an additional operation.;Area cultivated for soybean in North Dakota increased by 122% between 2000 and 2021 (USDA NASS data, 5 year rolling averages) US NRCS data indicates that total cropland in North Dakota has expanded over the same period by 2% (NRCS 2020a). The expansion of cropland for all crops in North Dakota in this period was supplied 100% from CRP land. The total cropland change 1997 to 2017 was 1.6% for all crops in North Dakota (NRCS 2020a).;Soil characteristics are based on IFA soil survey data (pH) and NRCS and USGS analysis (SOM, clay, slope). No anti-erosion practices are assumed in the dataset; instead, the erosion soil loss reported in the U.S. Natural Resources Conservation Service's Natural Resource Inventory is used.;References: USDA NASS (2021) Area, Production, Yield by State - Soybean - 2010-2021. US Department of Agriculture (USDA) National Agricultural Statistics Service. https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov (direct query: https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov/results/331F88CC-004E-34D2-B825-F8F65DAC7879);USDA NASS (2018) 2018 Irrigation and Water Management Survey  (2017 Census of Agriculture). US Department of Agriculture (USDA). https://www.nass.usda.gov/Publications/AgCensus/2017/Online_Resources/Farm_and_Ranch_Irrigation_Survey/index.php;NRCS (2020a) Land Cover/use of non-Federal rural land, by State and year, in the 2017 National Resources Inventory. USDA, Natural Resources Conservation Service. http://www.nrcs.usda.gov/Internet/NRCS_RCA/reports/nri_crop_nat.html, https://www.nrcs.usda.gov/wps/portal/nrcs/rca/national/technical/nra/rca/text/#NRI%20Cropland;CTIC (2020a) OpTIS - Operational Tillage Information System. Conservation Technology Information Center (CTIC). https://www.ctic.org/optis_tabular_query accessed March 23, 2021;Iowa Soil Survey & Digital Soil Data: ISPAID. Version 8.1.1 (2017). https://www.extension.iastate.edu/soils/ispaid

This activity starts with soil cultivation after the harvest of the previous crop.

This dataset includes cultivation of the field prior to planting, field treatments, planting, applications of nutrients and pesticides, and harvest. It ends with harvested maize grain at the farm gate, prior to storage.

location.name: United States of America, North Dakota

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The valid period covers 2014-01-01 through 2021-12-31 based on primary data sources. The production volumes, areas and applications are covered by data throughout the time period (annual for production and area, alternate years for applications). Due to disruption in 2020, some USDA data was reported for 2021 instead. Because the specific pesticides used show time-dependent trends, the most recent 3 years of data are used to avoid underweighting the most dominant pesticides currently used and to avoid skewing impacts based on compounds no longer in use. Field operations are based on current enterprise crop budgets and change little year to year.  Data for manure applications were only available for time periods prior to the valid period but represent the best available option.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Production of soy bean in North Dakota (US-ND).
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: This dataset reflects current practice for soy bean in North Dakota as of 2022.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription:
Mineral fertiliser applications are crop and location (state and sub-state levels) specific for nutrient applied, based on survey data compiled by the USDA National Agricultural Statistics Service. Specific fertilisers are extrapolated from mineral fertiliser applications to  soy bean in North Dakota and market consumption in the US (ecoinvent and IFA 2019).  Organic fertiliser types are extrapolated from animal manure use data for soybean in North Dakota (state-level) based on data collected by the USDA Economic Research Service for 2010, 2005 and 2000 and current materials on livestock levels. Where available data for liquid/slurry/solid shares and/or for animal source shares are incomplete, the shares have been normalized using the data provided.  Rotations are based on published analysis and classification of Cropland Data Layer GIS data for 2012-2018 and other sources (Socolar et al 2021 ). The US average is used for the state level values based on similarity shown in source maps, with the exception of MO and KS (significantly more area multi-crop rotations, with rotations of alfalfa and oats).  More than 75% of Midwestern soy is in annual rotation with corn, the remainder in more complex rotations involving oats, alfalfa or/and pasture on multiyear schedules. Generally soy rotations alternate years. Rotations that are predominantly corn/soy (e.g., CPCSCS & SCPCSC) have also been grouped as corn-soy rotation, assuming the overall trend will continue and the year of pasture is intermittent.  The rotation pattern is assumed to be steady throughout the period, consistent with number of years classified.  Data about tillage practices are from crop-specific GIS data for soy encompassing the dataset years (OpTIS 2020).  Soil characteristics, including pH and clay content, are extrapolated from (Hollinger S E 1995) and (Bruulsema T and Jones J D 2021) data reported for 2020 (pH, SOM) and 1995 (clay and slope), and taken as valid for the full time period.  Slope is consistent with 2009 USGS data showing 69% of the crop on farmland with slope under 1% and 83% less than 2%. Drainage tile data from 2012 (reported to USDA for the 2012 agricultural census) is extrapolated as valid from that date through the rest of the time period of the dataset and the distribution of drainage is treated as homogenous for all field crops. Machine usage is modelled with midwestern US diesel consumption and field operations set out by the regional agricultural extension office and crop budgets (Lazarus 2020, ISU 2015-2021).  Machine sizes (power) are approximate but based on common, recent surveys and equipment analyses (Lazarus 2020).  Transports are modelled with standard distances.  Emissions are calculated with standard methods according to ecoinvent documentation (Nemecek and Schnetzer, 2011. '01 crop production-direct field emissions natural resources' v1.2, August 2011, available at ) and the World Food LCA Database guidelines and the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool. Pesticide data is sometimes withheld in the NASS database to avoid disclosing data for individual operations (denoted with "D" in the data returned for the query, indicating a non-zero but withheld value). Where there is obfuscated, non-zero data for particular compounds, the crop-specific U.S. average (calculated from the USDA NASS data, which covers a subset of states, generally those with non-negligible production of the particular crop) are used.  For states with all (D) entries (i.e., the compound has been reported as used â€“ non-zero -- but data cannot be shown), the average quantity and variability of the application rate for that compound across all of the specific crop in the US in the same time period is used. For states with a single non-D data year in the dataset timeframe, that data value is uded and the variability is set to the variability of the application rate for that compound across all of the specific crop in the US in the relevant time period. 
Note that this U.S. soybean average value and standard deviation is neither production nor area weighted, as the application rate depends on many factors and this value is intended to represent the range of use. Instead, the average percent of treated acres for the class in that state is used. That is, if the average share of planted area across all non-zero, non-withheld values for fungicide treatment is 15%, then the US average application rate for the withheld data fungicide is scaled by 15% to reflect the effective average treatment per ha for that compound on the particular crop in the state.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Data is obtained from state, county and national statistics, agricultural extension offices, and published literature. Data for production, yields, applications of NPKS fertilisers, applications of pesticides, row width, and irrigation (if any) was obtained from the US Dept of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics Service and in most cases provides high-quality data spanning the dataset time period. Field operations and energy use are from enterprise crop budgets provided by local agricultural extensions offices and their farmer survey data. Literature data is used where USDA and agricultural extension guidance and data are not available. Uncertainty distribution types and statistical parameters have been based where possible on the underlying data itself, primarily normal distributions for data from USDA NASS. Otherwise, lognormal distributions are selected for use with Pedigree scores.

Mesotrione emission to agricultural soil (2.221E-02 kg/ha).  Pesticides are assumed to be ultimately 100% emitted to soil. Average over state-wide reported cropped area of soybean for all tillage practices (CTIC 2020a) and across all rotation patterns (Socolar et al 2021 ) - calculated from specified herbicide/insecticide/fungicide quantity applied to treated acres weighted by share of acres treated with that herbicide/insecticide/fungicide (2015,2017,2018,2020-USDA NASS data,  USDA NASS 2021e) 
 NASS does not contain numerical values for a number of pesticides widely used in soybean, are reported have no numerical data reported in NASS, as the values are hidden. For the most significant of those (those with more than 10 non-zero but withheld entries), the dataset uses other NASS entries to estimate the quantity if numerical entries are available.  The quantity used in the dataset for those pesticides is taken from maize if available, because the widespread one-year soybean-maize rotation cycle leads to more consistent usages. For the ones not covered in the numerical data for maize, the national average from NASS data is used if NASS contains non-withheld data. Where no numerical data are available in NASS, the item is excluded to avoid inconsistency with the pesticide usage matrix based on NASS data. 
Pesticide data is sometimes withheld in the NASS database to avoid disclosing data for individual operations (denoted with "D" in the data returned for the query, indicating a non-zero but withheld value). Where there is obfuscated, non-zero data for particular compounds, the crop-specific U.S. average (calculated from the USDA NASS data, which covers a subset of states, generally those with non-negligible production of the particular crop) are used.  For states with all (D) entries (i.e., the compound has been reported as used â€“ non-zero -- but data cannot be shown), the average quantity and variability of the application rate for that compound across all of the specific crop in the US in the same time period is used. For states with a single non-D data year in the dataset timeframe, that data value is uded and the variability is set to the variability of the application rate for that compound across all of the specific crop in the US in the relevant time period. 
Note that this U.S. soy average value and standard deviation is neither production nor area weighted, as the application rate depends on many factors and this value is intended to represent the range of use. Instead, the average percent of treated acres for the class in that state is used. That is, if the average share of planted area across all non-zero, non-withheld values for fungicide treatment is 15%, then the US average application rate for the withheld data fungicide is scaled by 15% to reflect the effective average treatment per ha for that compound on the particular crop in the state.

exchanges.description:
Land occupation per year (annual growing season).  Land is under rotation with other annual crop production (~80% corn-soy, ~20% corn-corn, Socolar et al 2021 ). US NRCS data indicates that total cropland in North Dakota has expanded 2% over the last 20 years, met entirely by land idled under the Conservation Reserve Program (CRP) (NRCS 2020a), resulting in a flux to/from annual crop that is essentially steady state. 
Annual production is 6.9 million tonnes from US Department of Agriculture (USDA NASS) 2021a on 2.6 million ha planted and 2.9 million ha harvested. Thus occupation is 04.618 ha/t or 46179.115 m2/t (4.6.179m2/kg). This overall land use is split into irrigated (0.62%) and non-irrigated (99.38%) based on agricultural census data () (2.85E-2 m2 planted/kg harvested maize of irrigated land, and 4.59E+0 m2 planted/kg harvested maize of non-irrigated land).
Sources:

exchanges.description:
Emissions of heavy metals to surface water arise from leaching (when drainage is present) and erosion. Emissions are estimated  based on the SALCA-heavy metal model (Freiermuth 2006) following the procedure in the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool (Faist Emmenegger, DÃ©lerce-Mauris and PortÃ© 2018 Models Integrated in Ecoinvent LCI Calculation Tool for Crop Production). The crop system carries a share of heavy metals emissions based on the ratio of cropping additions to total additions (additions to crop system divided by additions to crop system plus depostion from air and present in soils) Sources for heavy metals contents include: Leaching of heavy metals to surface water (Wolfensberger & Dinkel 1997), where drainage is installed ; Average heavy metal contents in crop soils, mg per kg soil, based on data for Switzerland (from Keller & Desaules, 2001). erosion rates are from US NRC National Resources Inventory, 2017. and Drainage on all cropland acres state-wide, including tile drainage (41.7%,) and ditch drainage (15.9%). USDA (2018) 2017 Census of Agriculture, Volume 1, Chapter 2: State Level Data - Table 41.  Land Use Practices:  2017 and 2012 (live table: https://www.nass.usda.gov/Quick_Stats/CDQT/chapter/2/table/41/state/US). (N.B. The uncertainty associated with manure data increases the uncertainty of the heavy metal emissions.)

exchanges.description:
Phosphorus emissions to surface water are based on the SALCA-P model (Prasuhn 2006), but using state-specific data for agricultural land (not crop-specific). The erosion and soil test values encompass the state-wide reported cropped area of soybean in Illinois for all tillage practices (OPTiS 2020) and across all rotation patterns (Socolar et al 2021).Soil Phosphorus losses are calculated from an annual soil loss from water erosion on agricultural soils in Illinois of 9.953t/ha/year (NRCS 2020b)with a Phosphorus soil concentration of 20mg/kg soil, the median value from 473,736 soil test samples reported for Illinois in the 2020 Soil Test Survey, (the average of the 2005, 2010, 2015, and 2020 median soil Phosphorus concentrations is 27.5mg/kg soil) (Bruulsema T and Jones J D 2021).No enrichment factor has been applied, because the phosphorus soil concentration samples are specifically agricultural land in the study area and thus any enrichment as a result of synthetic and organic fertilisers is already caputred in the soil test.An active cultivation duration of 6.8 months (0.56 year), covering cultivation through harvest (from weekly progress reports,USDA NASS 2021d), is used to adjust the annual erosion to the crop share (see Faist-Emmenegger et al 2009).No adjustment has been made for the presence of drainage (installed on 57.6% of crop land, USDA 2018) or any anti-erosion practices.Sources:

US NRCS data indicates that total cropland in North Dakota has expanded 2% over the last 20 years, met entirely by land idled under the Conservation Reserve Program (CRP) (NRCS 2020a), resulting in a flux to/from annual crop that is essentially steady state. 
Annual production is 6.9 million tonnes from US Department of Agriculture (USDA NASS) 2021a on 2.6 million ha planted and 2.9 million ha harvested. Thus occupation is 04.618 ha/t or 46179.115 m2/t (4.6.179m2/kg). This overall land use is split into irrigated (0.62%) and non-irrigated (99.38%) based on agricultural census data () (2.85E-2 m2 planted/kg harvested maize of irrigated land, and 4.59E+0 m2 planted/kg harvested maize of non-irrigated land).
Sources:

exchanges.description:
0.4633 ha/ha (2.14E-4 ha/kg soybean) market for application of plant protection product, by sprayer
The dataset has an effective number of passes for application of pesticides of 0.46 ha: 1.21 applications of herbicides on 22.4% of cropped area, 1.03 applications of insecticides on 13.6% of cropped area, 1.00 applications of fungicides on 5.2% of cropped area (USDA NASS 2021e). Application by sprayer accounts for 72% (0.33passes) and aircraft for 28% (0.13 passes). The budgets for soybean in North Dakota do not provide information for aerial pesticide application as an individual operation.  However, aerial application is in common use in North Dakota. An aerial pesticide application rate of  28% has been estimated from custom rate surveys for contracted farm operations (NDSU Extension 2020; NDSU Extension 2020; Plastina A and Johanns A (2021) Iowa Farm Custom Rate Survey, 2021 (2018, 2019, 2020). Cooperative Extension Service, Iowa State University of Science and Technology. https://www.extension.iastate.edu/agdm/crops/pdf/a3-10.pdf ; Plastina, Johanns, Massman (2020) 2020 Iowa Farm Custom Rate Survey File A3-10. Cooperative Extension Service, Iowa State University of Science and Technology. https://iastate.app.box.com/embed/s/hbsel0lckc7vle74v4jkg7mf0ph3z39s/file/630724245464 ; Plastina, Johanns, Wynne (2019) 2019 Iowa Farm Custom Rate Survey File A3-10. Cooperative Extension Service, Iowa State University of Science and Technology. https://www.extension.iastate.edu/monroe/sites/www.extension.iastate.edu/files/monroe/2019%20Custom%20Rate%20Survey.pdf ; Plastina, Johanns, Welter (2018) 2018 Iowa Farm Custom Rate Survey File A3-10. Cooperative Extension Service, Iowa State University of Science and Technology. https://www.extension.iastate.edu/hancock/sites/www.extension.iastate.edu/files/hancock/2018_CustomRateSurvey.pdf ).
Because aerial application is almost universally contracted service, it is most often not included in crop-specific enterprise budgets as a separate line item, instead being included under "custom" or "miscellaneous". Consequently, this dataset uses  the ratio of custom farm rate survey responses for aerial application to the total respondents to provide a state crop level average estimate of aerial applications.  This value covers all farmers responding and does not distinguish among crops. The National Agricultural Aviation Association's estimates that approximately 28% of all US cropland (excluding range, pasture, and forest lands) is treated by aircraft annually (NAAA 2019, NAAA 2020).
Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance.  (NDSU Extension 2022).  Operations are matched to equipment type and where multiple options are available, the share of each is determined from guidance and annual farmer survey data (Custom Rate Summaries) for contracted operations/equipment.Where an operation applies only to a portion of the harvested area, the number of passes has been scaled by the % of harvested area to which it applies (e.g., manure spreading or insecticide) as indicated by USDA statistics (applications) or USDA reports (manure use) or as otherwise indicated in enterprise crop budgets.
Source(s):

Emissions of heavy metals to surface water arise from leaching (when drainage is present) and erosion. Emissions are estimated  based on the SALCA-heavy metal model (Freiermuth 2006) following the procedure in the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool (Faist Emmenegger, DÃ©lerce-Mauris and PortÃ© 2018 Models Integrated in Ecoinvent LCI Calculation Tool for Crop Production). The crop system carries a share of heavy metals emissions based on the ratio of cropping additions to total additions (additions to crop system divided by additions to crop system plus depostion from air and present in soils) Sources for heavy metals contents include: Leaching of heavy metals to surface water (Wolfensberger & Dinkel 1997), where drainage is installed ; Average heavy metal contents in crop soils, mg per kg soil, based on data for Switzerland (from Keller & Desaules, 2001). erosion rates are from US NRC National Resources Inventory, 2017. and Drainage on all cropland acres state-wide, including tile drainage (41.7%,) and ditch drainage (15.9%). exchanges.description:
Transformation of land for planting.  Land is under rotation with other annual crop production (~80% corn-soy, ~20% corn-corn, Socolar et al 2021 ).  US NRCS data indicates that total cropland in North Dakota has expanded 2% over the last 20 years, met entirely by land idled under the Conservation Reserve Program (CRP) (NRCS 2020a), resulting in a flux to/from annual crop that is essentially steady state. 
Annual production is 6.9 million tonnes from US Department of Agriculture (USDA NASS) 2021a on 2.6 million ha planted and 2.9 million ha harvested. Thus occupation is 04.618 ha/t or 46179.115 m2/t (4.6.179m2/kg). This overall land use is split into irrigated (0.62%) and non-irrigated (99.38%) based on agricultural census data () (2.85E-2 m2 planted/kg harvested maize of irrigated land, and 4.59E+0 m2 planted/kg harvested maize of non-irrigated land).

exchanges.description:
atrazine emission to agricultural soil (1.401E-01 kg/ha).  Pesticides are assumed to be ultimately 100% emitted to soil. Average over state-wide reported cropped area of soybean for all tillage practices (CTIC 2020a) and across all rotation patterns (Socolar et al 2021 ) - calculated from specified herbicide/insecticide/fungicide quantity applied to treated acres weighted by share of acres treated with that herbicide/insecticide/fungicide (2015,2017,2018,2020-USDA NASS data,  USDA NASS 2021e) 
 NASS does not contain numerical values for a number of pesticides widely used in soybean, are reported have no numerical data reported in NASS, as the values are hidden. For the most significant of those (those with more than 10 non-zero but withheld entries), the dataset uses other NASS entries to estimate the quantity if numerical entries are available.  The quantity used in the dataset for those pesticides is taken from maize if available, because the widespread one-year soybean-maize rotation cycle leads to more consistent usages. For the ones not covered in the numerical data for maize, the national average from NASS data is used if NASS contains non-withheld data. Where no numerical data are available in NASS, the item is excluded to avoid inconsistency with the pesticide usage matrix based on NASS data. 
Pesticide data is sometimes withheld in the NASS database to avoid disclosing data for individual operations (denoted with "D" in the data returned for the query, indicating a non-zero but withheld value). Where there is obfuscated, non-zero data for particular compounds, the crop-specific U.S. average (calculated from the USDA NASS data, which covers a subset of states, generally those with non-negligible production of the particular crop) are used.  For states with all (D) entries (i.e., the compound has been reported as used â€“ non-zero -- but data cannot be shown), the average quantity and variability of the application rate for that compound across all of the specific crop in the US in the same time period is used. For states with a single non-D data year in the dataset timeframe, that data value is uded and the variability is set to the variability of the application rate for that compound across all of the specific crop in the US in the relevant time period. 
Note that this U.S. soy average value and standard deviation is neither production nor area weighted, as the application rate depends on many factors and this value is intended to represent the range of use. Instead, the average percent of treated acres for the class in that state is used. That is, if the average share of planted area across all non-zero, non-withheld values for fungicide treatment is 15%, then the US average application rate for the withheld data fungicide is scaled by 15% to reflect the effective average treatment per ha for that compound on the particular crop in the state.

exchanges.description:
1.54E-4 kg superphosphate/kg soybean 
Quantities of specific fertiliser are calculated based on US fertiliser market share and nutrient compositions from IFA data to meet total nutrient demand N-P-K-S: 2.77--11.48--0.43--0.17 kg/ha  (USDA NASS data for  2015, 2017, 2018, 2020). Quantity of specific fertiliser calculated from: average total N application (2010, 2014, 2016, 2018) reported cropped area of specified crop (includes all rotation patterns) and share of fertilisers in U.S. consumption mix (ecoinvent and IFA 2019) times each fertiliser's P2O5 to N ratio (IFA), subtracted from the application rate for the necessary nutrient, and multiplied by the mass of the compound over the mass of P2O5 in the compound.
Sources: 
USDA NASS (2021) SOYBEAN- APPLICATIONS, MEASURED IN LB / ACRE / YEAR, AVG (fertilizer and pesticides, amount, number of applications) - 2000-2021. US Department of Agriculture (USDA) National Agricultural Statistics Service. https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov (direct query: https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov/results/1D738304-38A8-3977-B7BA-B67A7AF33530) ; Ecoinvent U.S. consumption mix for N fertilisers, from IFA data; IFA (2021) Nutrient content in percentage - IFA Fertilizer Converter. International Fertilizer Association. https://www.ifastat.org/converter/fertilizer-converter/ accessed 2021-06-24

exchanges.description:
The total effective manure application rate of 819 kg/ha (0.378 kg/kg soybean) is calculated from USDA ERS data for amount of manure applied (21.6 kg/ha; 0.38 kg/kg soybean) on share of crop area treated (3.8%)  (years available: 2002, 2006) USDA ARMS 2015. The manure data has significant uncertainty due to both the age of the available data and the statistical limitations imposed by confidentiality for USDA survey respondents.
None of the applied manure is in liquid form, calculated from the share of dry, semi-dry and slurry and lagoon manure applied  from ARMS data. USDA describes the liquid/slurry and dry manure shares as "Statistically unreliable due to a low sample size" (USDA ARMS 2015a). 100.% of manure from cattle.  USDA data shows zero share from swine manure.USDA data shows zero share from poultry manure. Cattle manure is apportioned between solid and liquid consistent with USDA estimated shares . Total mass solid manure is 3.78E-1 kg/kg soybean. USDA ARMS (2015) Agricultural Resource Management Survey (ARMS) Farm Financial and Crop Production Practices: Manure Table, Corn. USDA. https://data.ers.usda.gov/reports.aspx?ID=17883

exchanges.description:
Land occupation per year (annual growing season).  Land is under rotation with other annual crop production (~80% corn-soy, ~20% corn-corn, Socolar et al 2021 ). US NRCS data indicates that total cropland in North Dakota has expanded 2% over the last 20 years, met entirely by land idled under the Conservation Reserve Program (CRP) (NRCS 2020a), resulting in a flux to/from annual crop that is essentially steady state. 
Annual production is 6.9 million tonnes from US Department of Agriculture (USDA NASS) 2021a on 2.6 million ha planted and 2.9 million ha harvested. Thus occupation is 04.618 ha/t or 46179.115 m2/t (4.6.179m2/kg). This overall land use is split into irrigated (0.62%) and non-irrigated (99.38%) based on agricultural census data () (2.85E-2 m2 planted/kg harvested maize of irrigated land, and 4.59E+0 m2 planted/kg harvested maize of non-irrigated land).
Sources:

4.62E-4 ha/kg combine harvesting ( 1 pass per year). 
Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance. Operations are matched to equipment type and where multiple options are available, the share of each is determined from guidance and annual farmer survey data (Custom Rate Summaries) for contracted operations/equipment. Field cultivation and tillage operations are specific to the tillage regime used.Â Soybean is  44% reduced till, 42% no till, and 13% conventional till in North Dakota (CTIC 2020a).Used with harvesting cart.

exchanges.description:
Transformation of land for planting.  Land is under rotation with other annual crop production (~80% corn-soy, ~20% corn-corn, Socolar et al 2021 ).  US NRCS data indicates that total cropland in North Dakota has expanded 2% over the last 20 years, met entirely by land idled under the Conservation Reserve Program (CRP) (NRCS 2020a), resulting in a flux to/from annual crop that is essentially steady state. 
Annual production is 6.9 million tonnes from US Department of Agriculture (USDA NASS) 2021a on 2.6 million ha planted and 2.9 million ha harvested. Thus occupation is 04.618 ha/t or 46179.115 m2/t (4.6.179m2/kg). This overall land use is split into irrigated (0.62%) and non-irrigated (99.38%) based on agricultural census data () (2.85E-2 m2 planted/kg harvested maize of irrigated land, and 4.59E+0 m2 planted/kg harvested maize of non-irrigated land).
Sources:

exchanges.description:
0.1315 ha/ha (6.07E-5 ha/kg soybean) application of plant protection product, by airplane
The dataset has an effective number of passes for application of pesticides of 0.46 ha: 1.21 applications of herbicides on 22.4% of cropped area, 1.03 applications of insecticides on 13.6% of cropped area, 1.00 applications of fungicides on 5.2% of cropped area (USDA NASS 2021e). Application by sprayer accounts for 72% (0.33passes) and aircraft for 28% (0.13 passes). The budgets for soybean in North Dakota do not provide information for aerial pesticide application as an individual operation.  However, aerial application is in common use in North Dakota. An aerial pesticide application rate of  28% has been estimated from custom rate surveys for contracted farm operations (NDSU Extension 2020; NDSU Extension 2020; Plastina A and Johanns A (2021) Iowa Farm Custom Rate Survey, 2021 (2018, 2019, 2020). Cooperative Extension Service, Iowa State University of Science and Technology. https://www.extension.iastate.edu/agdm/crops/pdf/a3-10.pdf ; Plastina, Johanns, Massman (2020) 2020 Iowa Farm Custom Rate Survey File A3-10. Cooperative Extension Service, Iowa State University of Science and Technology. https://iastate.app.box.com/embed/s/hbsel0lckc7vle74v4jkg7mf0ph3z39s/file/630724245464 ; Plastina, Johanns, Wynne (2019) 2019 Iowa Farm Custom Rate Survey File A3-10. Cooperative Extension Service, Iowa State University of Science and Technology. https://www.extension.iastate.edu/monroe/sites/www.extension.iastate.edu/files/monroe/2019%20Custom%20Rate%20Survey.pdf ; Plastina, Johanns, Welter (2018) 2018 Iowa Farm Custom Rate Survey File A3-10. Cooperative Extension Service, Iowa State University of Science and Technology. https://www.extension.iastate.edu/hancock/sites/www.extension.iastate.edu/files/hancock/2018_CustomRateSurvey.pdf ).
Because aerial application is almost universally contracted service, it is most often not included in crop-specific enterprise budgets as a separate line item, instead being included under "custom" or "miscellaneous". Consequently, this dataset uses  the ratio of custom farm rate survey responses for aerial application to the total respondents to provide a state crop level average estimate of aerial applications.  This value covers all farmers responding and does not distinguish among crops. The National Agricultural Aviation Association's estimates that approximately 28% of all US cropland (excluding range, pasture, and forest lands) is treated by aircraft annually (NAAA 2019, NAAA 2020).
Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance.  (NDSU Extension 2022).  Operations are matched to equipment type and where multiple options are available, the share of each is determined from guidance and annual farmer survey data (Custom Rate Summaries) for contracted operations/equipment.Where an operation applies only to a portion of the harvested area, the number of passes has been scaled by the % of harvested area to which it applies (e.g., manure spreading or insecticide) as indicated by USDA statistics (applications) or USDA reports (manure use) or as otherwise indicated in enterprise crop budgets.
Source(s): 
NDSU Extension 2020; Plastina A and Johanns A (2021) Iowa Farm Custom Rate Survey, 2021 (2018, 2019, 2020). exchanges.description:
3.8E-2 kg/ha (1.75E-5 kg/kg soybean) solid manure loading and spreading, by hydraulic loader and spreader
The total effective manure application rate of 819 kg/ha (0.378 kg/kg soybean) is calculated from USDA ERS data for amount of manure applied (21.6 kg/ha; 0.38 kg/kg soybean) on share of crop area treated (3.8%)  (years available: 2002, 2006) USDA ARMS 2015. The manure data has significant uncertainty due to both the age of the available data and the statistical limitations imposed by confidentiality for USDA survey respondents.
None of the applied manure is in liquid form, calculated from the share of dry, semi-dry and slurry and lagoon manure applied  from ARMS data. USDA describes the liquid/slurry and dry manure shares as "Statistically unreliable due to a low sample size" (USDA ARMS 2015a). 100.% of manure from cattle.  USDA data shows zero share from swine manure.USDA data shows zero share from poultry manure. Cattle manure is apportioned between solid and liquid consistent with USDA estimated shares The effective application rates are 819.3 kg solid manure per ha (0.E+0 kg/kg soybean).

Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance.  (NDSU Extension 2022).  Operations are matched to equipment type and where multiple options are available, the share of each is determined from guidance and annual farmer survey data (Custom Rate Summaries) for contracted operations/equipment. Where an operation applies only to a portion of the harvested area, the number of passes has been scaled by the % of harvested area to which it applies (e.g., manure spreading or insecticide) as indicated by USDA statistics (applications) or USDA reports (manure use) or as otherwise indicated in enterprise crop budgets. 
Source(s): 
USDA ARMS (2015) Agricultural Resource Management Survey (ARMS) Farm Financial and Crop Production Practices: Manure Table, Corn. USDA. https://data.ers.usda.gov/reports.aspx?ID=17883 
Beegle D and Peters J. (2019) Common Manure Test Results Conversions. National Cooperative Extension Resource, Livestock And Poultry Environmental Learning Community (Lpelc). https://lpelc.org/common-manure-test-results-conversions/ accessed October 5, 2021

exchanges.description:
0.128 ha/ha (5.91E-5 ha/kg soybean) fertilising, by injection
The dataset has an effective number of passes for application of mineral fertilisers (NPKS) of 1.28: 1.08 N applications on 47.3% of cropped area, 1.00 P applications on 51.0% of cropped area, 1.03 K applications on 12.8% of cropped area, and 1.08 S applications on 12.3% of cropped area (USDA NASS 2021e, NPKS data from 2015, 2017, 2018, 2020). Applications of N are split between anhydrous ammonia and other NPK fertilisers because they are generally applied differently, with different equipment. Anhydrous ammonia application (knifing/injection) is calculated as market share of N that is anhydrous ammonia * total N applications. Other N application is then: total USDA N applications less applications of anhydrous ammoni.  (here, 25.21%). Thus, the dataset includes 0.38 anhydrous ammonia applications via injection (0.25 * 47.3% of crop area with applied N) and 1.15 other fertiliser applications via broadcast.

Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance.  (NDSU Extension 2022).  Operations are matched to equipment type and where multiple options are available, the share of each is determined from guidance and annual farmer survey data (Custom Rate Summaries) for contracted operations/equipment. Where an operation applies only to a portion of the harvested area, the number of passes has been scaled by the % of harvested area to which it applies (e.g., manure spreading or insecticide) as indicated by USDA statistics (applications) or USDA reports (manure use) or as otherwise indicated in enterprise crop budgets.
Source(s): 
USDA NASS (2021) SOYBEAN- APPLICATIONS, MEASURED IN LB / ACRE / YEAR, AVG (fertilizer and pesticides, amount, number of applications) - 2000-2021. US Department of Agriculture (USDA) National Agricultural Statistics Service. https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov (direct query: https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov/results/1D738304-38A8-3977-B7BA-B67A7AF33530) ; NDSU Extension (2022) Projected crop budgets. exchanges.description:
CO2 emissions from use of urea fertilisers and lime, 7.13E-1 kg/ha (3.29E-4 kg/kg soybean): 7.132E-1 kg/ha from urea and urea ammonium nitrate; 0.E+0 kg/ha from lime. 
Emissions are calculated following the IPCC NIR Guidelines, Â§11.3 and Â§11.4, using IPCC NIR equations 11.12 (lime) and 11.13 (urea) (mass of lime/urea * emissions factor for lime/urea) with Tier 1 emissions factors (IPCC 2006b).  EF limestone = 0.12 kg CO2-C/kg limestone (0.06-0.12, uniform) and EF urea = 0.2 kg CO2-C/kg urea (0.1-0.2, uniform) applied to both urea and the approximately 35% of UAN that is urea. The result is converted from kg CO2-C to kg CO2 (multiplying by the molar mass of CO2/mass of C in CO2 = 44.01/12)

The crop system carries a share of heavy metals emissions based on the ratio of cropping additions to total additions (additions to crop system divided by additions to crop system plus depostion from air and present in soils) Sources for heavy metals contents include: Leaching of heavy metals to surface water (Wolfensberger & Dinkel 1997), where drainage is installed ; Average heavy metal contents in crop soils, mg per kg soil, based on data for Switzerland (from Keller & Desaules, 2001). erosion rates are from US NRC National Resources Inventory, 2017. and Drainage on all cropland acres state-wide, including tile drainage (41.7%,) and ditch drainage (15.9%). exchanges.description:
1.1532 ha/ha (5.33E-4 ha/kg soybean) fertilising, by broadcaster
The dataset has an effective number of passes for application of mineral fertilisers (NPKS) of 1.28: 1.08 N applications on 47.3% of cropped area, 1.00 P applications on 51.0% of cropped area, 1.03 K applications on 12.8% of cropped area, and 1.08 S applications on 12.3% of cropped area (USDA NASS 2021e, NPKS data from 2015, 2017, 2018, 2020). Applications of N are split between anhydrous ammonia and other NPK fertilisers because they are generally applied differently, with different equipment. Anhydrous ammonia application (knifing/injection) is calculated as market share of N that is anhydrous ammonia * total N applications. Other N application is then: total USDA N applications less applications of anhydrous ammoni.  (here, 25.21%). Thus, the dataset includes 0.38 anhydrous ammonia applications via injection (0.25 * 47.3% of crop area with applied N) and 1.15 other fertiliser applications via broadcast.

Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance.  (NDSU Extension 2022).  Operations are matched to equipment type and where multiple options are available, the share of each is determined from guidance and annual farmer survey data (Custom Rate Summaries) for contracted operations/equipment. Where an operation applies only to a portion of the harvested area, the number of passes has been scaled by the % of harvested area to which it applies (e.g., manure spreading or insecticide) as indicated by USDA statistics (applications) or USDA reports (manure use) or as otherwise indicated in enterprise crop budgets.
Source(s):

The crop system carries a share of heavy metals emissions based on the ratio of cropping additions to total additions (additions to crop system divided by additions to crop system plus depostion from air and present in soils) Sources for heavy metals contents include: Leaching of heavy metals to surface water (Wolfensberger & Dinkel 1997), where drainage is installed ; Average heavy metal contents in crop soils, mg per kg soil, based on data for Switzerland (from Keller & Desaules, 2001). erosion rates are from US NRC National Resources Inventory, 2017. and Drainage on all cropland acres state-wide, including tile drainage (41.7%,) and ditch drainage (15.9%). USDA (2018) 2017 Census of Agriculture, Volume 1, Chapter 2: State Level Data - Table 41. exchanges.description:
Emissions of heavy metals to soil are estimated based on the SALCA-heavy metal model (Freiermuth 2006) following the procedure in the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool (Faist Emmenegger, DÃ©lerce-Mauris and PortÃ© 2018 Models Integrated in Ecoinvent LCI Calculation Tool for Crop Production). The balance of heavy metal emissions to soils includes the net change from erosion, leaching, crop removal and fertilizer, manure, lime, planting and deposition.  The crop system carries a share of heavy metals emissions based on the ratio of cropping additions to total additions (additions to crop system divided by additions to crop system plus depostion from air and present in soils) Sources for heavy metals contents include: Heavy-metal contents of plant material, maize (mg/kg dry matter, from Freiermuth 2006). ; Leaching of heavy metals to surface water (Wolfensberger & Dinkel 1997), where drainage is installed ; Deposition of heavy metals to soils, mg per ha per year (Freiermuth 2006). ; Deposition of heavy metals to soils, mg per ha per year (Freiermuth 2006). ; Average heavy metal contents in crop soils, mg per kg soil, based on data for Switzerland (from Keller & Desaules, 2001). state and regional erosion rates are from US NRC National Resources Inventory, 2017. and Drainage on all cropland acres state-wide, including tile drainage (41.7%,) and ditch drainage (15.9%). USDA (2018) 2017 Census of Agriculture, Volume 1, Chapter 2: State Level Data - Table 41.  Land Use Practices:  2017 and 2012 (live table: https://www.nass.usda.gov/Quick_Stats/CDQT/chapter/2/table/41/state/US). US Department of Agriculture (USDA). https://www.nass.usda.gov/Publications/AgCensus/2017/Full_Report/Volume_1,_Chapter_2_US_State_Level/st99_2_0041_0041.pdf . Fertilizer, manure and pesticide application rates are based on USDA NASS data.
(N.B. The uncertainty associated with manure data increases the uncertainty of the heavy metal emissions.)

exchanges.description: Ammonia volatilised from applied mineral and organic fertilisers, 2.5 kg NH3/ha (1.15E-3kg NH3/kg soybean) total, 0.2 kg NH3/ha (1.15E-3 kg NH3/kg soybean) from synthetic fertilisers, 2.3 kg NH3/ha (1.05E-3 kg NH3/kg soybean) from manure. NH3 from volatilisation of mineral fertilisers is calculated using Tier 2 emission factors (temperate climate, specific fertiliser) from the European Environment Agency, EMEP/EEA 3Da1, Table3.2 (EEA 2019). NH3 from manure application is calculated with emission factors provided in EMEP/EEA 3.D.a.2.a (Animal manure applied to soils) (EEA 2019) for manure types used as (fraction TAN in total N)*(EF manure spreading per TAN) for each animal group and type. (kg NH3-N/kg N applied: cattle, solid: 0.474). The emissions from manure calculated here do not account for the change in N mineralization and phosphate runoff with incorporation type or time. Where impacts from manure application are expected to be significant, this should be considered as N volatilisation during and after application of manure ranges from as low as 1% N with direct injection to ~5% with immediate incorporation to 20-40% without incorporation (Sawyer J, Mallarino A P (2016) Using Manure Nutrients for Crop Production. Cooperative Extension Service, Iowa State University of Science and Technology. https://store.extension.iastate.edu/product/12874 and Midwast Plan Services MWPS-18, 3ed)..

6.13E-5 ha/kg tillage, cultivating, chiselling (0.133 effective pass(es) per year). 
Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance. Operations are matched to equipment type and where multiple options are available, the share of each is determined from guidance and annual farmer survey data (Custom Rate Summaries) for contracted operations/equipment. Field cultivation and tillage operations are specific to the tillage regime used.Â Soybean is  44% reduced till, 42% no till, and 13% conventional till in North Dakota (CTIC 2020a).This operation applies only to conventionally tilled fields.

NDSU Extension (2022) Projected crop budgets. North Dakota State University. https://www.ndsu.edu/agriculture/ag-hub/ag-topics/farm-management/crop-economics/projected-crop-budgets ; CTIC (2020a) OpTIS - Operational Tillage Information System.
